O2.sentence: By restoring the land, the project is creating work for nearby communities, offering an alternative to predation and deforestation, and providing environmental benefits.
The project has a positive impact on the surrounding population by providing long-term jobs, legal benefits, training, and health benefits.

The project helps conserve biodiversity by providing jobs in neighboring villages to reduce the impact of illegal logging, by protecting high-conservation-value areas that provide extended habitat for species, and by promoting sustainable practices to reduce pressure on natural ecosystems.

Sustainable Development Contributions: the project has benefited neighboring communities with safe drinking water services, continuous maintenance of water services within the farm property, and has benefited over 1,500 individuals; it has created full‑time and seasonal employment opportunities, employing 392 people, including 14 women (368 permanent, 24 seasonal), and has created more than 300 annual jobs; the project has avoided or removed tons of greenhouse gas emissions—during the monitoring period it achieved the removal of 121,707.49 tons of CO₂, and over the project lifetime it plans to remove 3.9 million tons of CO₂ over 42 years, with 394,784 tCO₂ removed to date; it has conserved 103 hectares of natural area within farm properties, keeping it as natural forest during the monitoring period, and has continuously conserved up to 103 hectares within farm properties.
In addition, as stated in previous sections, project activities provide economic opportunities for the local community (formal and permanent job opportunities).

The without-project scenario would not generate any additional community or biodiversity benefits, given that previous land uses provide few employment opportunities, little community involvement, and no ecosystem improvements.
The project brings benefits to offsite communities by providing additional employment opportunities, improving the local environment, and mitigating the impacts of climate change on the project zone.

Every year, provide economic opportunities for the community. CCB v3.0, VCS v4.4 stakeholder groups impacted: workers of participating farms, neighboring community members and leaders. Results: individuals employed during monitoring period (2016–) improving local income stability.

6. Afforestation, reforestation, and revegetation (ARR) – activities that increase carbon stocks in woody biomass (and sometimes soils) by establishing, increasing, or restoring vegetative cover through planting, sowing, or human-assisted natural regeneration of woody vegetation (VCS Program Definitions). CCB v2.0, VCS v3.0. MONITORING REPORT: CCB Version 2, VCS Version 3. Category Metric: Achievements during Monitoring Period. Achievements during the Project Lifetime: Number of hectares of existing production forest land in which IFM7 practices have occurred as a result of the project’s activities, measured against the without-project scenario. Number of hectares of non-forest land in which improved land management has occurred as a result of the project’s activities, measured against the without-project scenario. Total number of community members who have improved skills and/or knowledge resulting from training provided as part of project activities. Number of female community members who have improved skills and/or knowledge resulting from training provided as part of project activities. > 300. 5% total employment. Total number of people employed in project activities, expressed as number of full-time employees. Number of women employed in project activities, expressed as number of full-time employees. CCB Monitoring > 300. CCB Monitoring 5% total employment. 8. Employed in project activities means people directly working on project activities in return for compensation (financial or otherwise), including employees, contracted workers, sub-contracted workers, and community members that are paid to carry out project-related work.
Indirect benefits of the project, such as increased employment in nearby communities and worker benefits, are expected to decrease illegal activities such as illegal extraction of flora and fauna.

The project established 1,433.36 hectares of rubber tree plantations on degraded lands, sequestering an estimated 3,900,439 t CO2-e over 42 years. It created 302 permanent jobs with legal benefits, training, and health benefits, and offered life insurance, investment groups, and donations to local schools, infrastructure, and community projects. The plantations serve as a buffer zone and biological corridor, reducing deforestation, improving soil, restoring water recharge, and enhancing landscape aesthetics.

The project provides economic opportunities for the community, employing 392 individuals during 2016–2022 and improving local income stability. Community members support the project and communicate its benefits to others.
The project positively impacts the surrounding population by providing training and education benefits, tracking employment through training registries, and monitoring annually.
An estimated 5% of total employment will be women with improved livelihoods or income from the project.
The project creates jobs and benefits individuals through philanthropy, with community members supporting and communicating the project.
By the end of the project, 5% of total employment is expected to be female community members who have improved skills or knowledge through training.
During monitoring, 14 female community members improved their skills or knowledge through training, accounting for 5% of total employment.

The project creates long-term jobs for local communities, offering employment, training, and provision supplies. The number of jobs generated is recorded in company records and verified at each monitoring cycle.
The project improved the well-being of 392 women, contributing to over 300 total employment opportunities.
The project provides economic opportunities, creating jobs for the community as confirmed by VVB review and interviews.

O3.sentence: The project has a positive impact on the surrounding population by providing long-term jobs, legal benefits, training, and health benefits.
Describe the training provided for the project’s employees and relevant community members.

Through training and collaborative efforts, the project ensures that community members contribute to and benefit from biodiversity‑friendly practices, fostering a culture of conservation that extends beyond the project area.

The project intends to sustain climate, community, and biodiversity benefits beyond its lifetime through community empowerment, such as training in integrated pest control, forest management, fire control, worker safety, adherence to international and national norms, forest certifications, and the importance of conservation (see section 4.2 Net Positive Community Impacts).

The project established 1,433.36 hectares of rubber tree plantations on degraded lands, sequestering an estimated 3,900,439 t CO2-e over 42 years. It created 302 permanent jobs with legal benefits, training, and health benefits, and offered life insurance, investment groups, and donations to local schools, infrastructure, and community projects. The plantations serve as a buffer zone and biological corridor, reducing deforestation, improving soil, restoring water recharge, and enhancing landscape aesthetics.
The project positively impacts the surrounding population by providing training and education benefits, tracking employment through training registries, and monitoring annually.
The project conserves high-value forests and fragile ecosystems, promotes non-chemical pest management, and invests in expertise to maintain ecological functions and forest integrity.
The project started tapping natural rubber sap and providing training to new employees.

The project implements long-term management plans integrating timber, rubber, and environmental services, minimizing waste, and encouraging local processing of forest products. It invests in expertise and innovative systems to recycle materials and develop technology to process rubber wood.
Over 300 community members are expected to improve skills and knowledge through project training.
Written guidelines to control erosion and protect water resources were prepared, and personnel were trained in soil and water conservation.
Community involvement in planning and interactive consultations enhances understanding of project objectives, increasing engagement and acceptance.
The project ran from Year 7 to Year 36, during which natural rubber sap was tapped and new employees received training.
During the monitoring period, 392 community members improved their skills or knowledge through training, and overall the project benefited more than 300 people.
By the end of the project, 5% of total employment is expected to be female community members who have improved skills or knowledge through training.
During monitoring, 14 female community members improved their skills or knowledge through training, accounting for 5% of total employment.

The project creates long-term jobs for local communities, offering employment, training, and provision supplies. The number of jobs generated is recorded in company records and verified at each monitoring cycle.

The project provides opportunities for community involvement in planning through interactive consultations with local and indigenous communities, volunteers, and stakeholders. This increases community engagement, acceptance, and knowledge, aligning project goals with community expectations.

During the monitoring period, 392 community members improved their skills and knowledge through project training. The training covered CCB Monitoring Plan version 2, NEOSA biodiversity monitoring, and monitoring system and management.
The project provides opportunities for community involvement in planning through interactive consultations, increasing community engagement, acceptance, and knowledge.

The project coordinates information flows, evaluates commitments, provides technical training, and manages administrative matters to support VCS and CCBS implementation. Stakeholder consultations and surveys are conducted to gather input and address concerns.
Personnel involved in the farm receive technical training on good practices for rubber plantation management, building capacity.

During the monitoring period, 121,668.49 tonnes of CO2 were removed, with plans to sequester 3,900,439 tonnes over 42 years. Additionally, female community members received training that improved their skills.
The project leads socialization events and monitors community engagement through coordination by NEOSA.

O5.sentence: Multiple revenue sources are considered for the project; carbon credit revenues allow participants to develop protection measures, responsible management—especially during the period being reported when rubber prices have fallen significantly—and projects are implemented on degrading and degraded lands with low productivity for agriculture and cattle.
Additionally, project revenues will help fund monitoring of the project's climate, community, and biodiversity goals.

Although benefits vary depending on the project area due to proximity to local communities and resource access, the project offered life insurance. Some projects created investment groups to incentivize savings. Donations were given to local schools and communities, including water tanks, gas for volunteer firefighters, resource donations for infrastructure development, road restoration, supervised practices in administrative offices, authorized use of local rivers and springs, donations for local festivities, church remodeling, and pipes for local sewage.

The project established 1,433.36 hectares of rubber tree plantations on degraded lands, sequestering an estimated 3,900,439 t CO2-e over 42 years. It created 302 permanent jobs with legal benefits, training, and health benefits, and offered life insurance, investment groups, and donations to local schools, infrastructure, and community projects. The plantations serve as a buffer zone and biological corridor, reducing deforestation, improving soil, restoring water recharge, and enhancing landscape aesthetics.
The project is implemented on degraded lands with low agricultural productivity, enabling participants to develop protection measures funded by carbon credit revenues.

The project provides environmental protection, increased employment, better economic income, permanent employment, water source protection, educational support through school internships, and donations to local communities.
The project coordinates carbon credit registration, issuance, and trading, supporting emissions reductions.
Communities indirectly benefit from donations and outreach, with documentation such as invoices and letters verifying the aid provided.

The project issues and trades verified emission reductions, coordinating with a VCS approved registry. Personnel at each farm monitor and archive raw data, and the project identifies buyers and negotiates commercial terms. This generates revenue that supports project activities.
To mitigate the risk of falling carbon credit prices, the project diversifies revenue sources, enabling participants to develop protection measures.

O6.sentence: Infrastructure improvements within the farm, aimed at boosting production, will also help nearby communities by providing better roads and access.
Assistance with community infrastructure (such as roads) when it benefits the farm and the community. Authorized passage through the farm for low‑risk individuals who have a valid reason.

R3.sentence: Workers derive income and livelihood directly from project activities and are directly impacted.
Provide opportunities for community involvement in planning. The community derives economic benefits from the project, including increased women's empowerment.
Community members benefit from project philanthropy and derive economic benefits, with 277 participants in community events in 2018 and 2022.

The community group reported increased employment opportunities, better economic income, educational support, improved environmental protection, and enhanced infrastructure and morale through donations for local festivities, sewage, and water tank projects.
The project has improved the livelihoods of 392 women, contributing to increased income.

R4.sentence: The project provides economic opportunities for communities and for members of the community.
Workers derive income and livelihood directly from project activities and are directly impacted.
Neighboring communities participate in the economic opportunities provided by the project and continue to have a positive perception of project activities.
Neighbouring communities participate in the economic opportunities provided by the project and continue to have a positive perception of project activities.
The project provides economic opportunities for the community, and the community derives economic benefits from it.
The project expects to improve livelihoods for more than 300 people by the end of its lifetime.
During monitoring, 392 people improved livelihoods or income from project activities; overall, more than 300 people benefited.
During the monitoring period, 392 community members improved their skills or knowledge through training, and overall the project benefited more than 300 people.

The community group reported increased employment opportunities, better economic income, educational support, improved environmental protection, and enhanced infrastructure and morale through donations for local festivities, sewage, and water tank projects.
The project has improved the livelihoods of 392 women, contributing to increased income.
The project has improved livelihoods for 392 people, as documented in monitoring plans and stakeholder socialization reports.
A total of 392 community members experienced improved livelihoods and well-being due to project activities.

I3.sentence: Provide opportunities for community involvement in planning. The community derives economic benefits from the project, including increased women's empowerment.

The project provides equal employment opportunities, increasing women's participation to 14 employees (~5%) and empowering them through training and employment. Community members support and communicate these benefits.
An estimated 5% of total employment will be women with improved livelihoods or income from the project.
The project provides equal employment opportunities, increasing women empowerment and participation in community leadership roles.
